title: What are some of the best writing tips from Hemingway and Faulkner? - Quora

response.answer_text: What a huge question. Hemingway said it best himself: “I think you should learn about writing from everybody who has ever written that has anything to teach you.” I have no idea what that means. But it sounds impressive. But quite seriously, Hemingway didn’t officially talk about his writing much, as we have most of it from letters, private memoirs and informal remarks. But he came from reporting, and his writing screams out, “Let the reader feel for himself, and let me just describe what they’re seeing.” And so it’s tight and vivid writing, with lots of short sentences and strong verbs. He sure knew how to create pictures in the readers’ heads, and he coined the word “ice berg style” because it was cold, but the reader could project their own warmth or passions into it, but it was under the surface. Here’s my favorite tip from Faulkner, who said the best training for writing is reading copious amounts of anything: “Keep it amateur. You’re not writing for money but for pleasure. It should be fun. And it should be exciting. Maybe not as you write, but after it’s done you should feel an excitement, a passion. That doesn’t mean feeling proud, sitting there gloating over what you’ve done. It means you know you’ve done your best. Next time it’s going to be better.” And one last Faulkner pearl: “You can always find time to write. Anybody who says he can’t is living under false pretenses. To that extent depend on inspiration. Don’t wait. When you have an inspiration put it down. Don’t wait until later and when you have more time and then try to recapture the mood and add flourishes. You can never recapture the mood with the vividness of its first impression.”
